sec.title: Objectives
sec.p: Determine the formation of peripheral and central nervous system (CNS and PNS) transitional zone (PCTZ) along the postnatal mouse cochlear nerve.

sec.title: Study Design
sec.p: Prospective, basic science.

sec.title: Setting
sec.p: Research laboratory.

sec.title: Subjects and Methods
sec.p: A novel cryosection model of cochlea-cochlear nerve-brainstem was used in this study. The sections were harvested from a total of 45 mice in 9 groups of postnatal-day-0 to postnatal-day-60 mice (n = 5). Differential interference contrast microscopy and immunofluorescence were used to study the formation of PCTZ along the cochlear nerve of the postnatal mouse.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The CNS tissue extended peripherally along the cochlear nerve from postnatal-day-0 to postnatal-day-7 and then stably located at the level of the spiral lamina of the basal cochlear turn. The PCTZ reached a mature pattern along the cochlear nerve after postnatal-day-7. A long segment of the CNS tissue extended along the cochlear nerve in the postnatal mouse.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In the early postnatal days, the PCTZ extended peripherally toward the cochlea and obtains a mature pattern along the neonatal mouse cochlear nerve.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Recent advances in stem cell technology offer new opportunity for the replacement of damaged cellular components in sensorineural hearing loss. For instance, exogenous cells have been implanted into the inner ear with the aim of substituting injured spiral ganglion neurons.1,2 In spiral ganglion replacement, one of the central questions is whether peripherally implanted cells are able to form neural contacts with the central auditory system, which includes the formation of the peripheral nervous system (PNS) and central nervous system (CNS) transitional zone (PCTZ). To rebuild PCTZ along the cochlear nerve, it is fundamental to understand the development of PCTZ along the cochlear nerve. Although several reports have begun to address some of the issues in this field,3-5 the knowledge of PCTZ formation along the cochlear nerve is still very limited.

In vertebrates, the CNS and PNS interface at the PCTZ, where motor axons exit and sensory axons enter the CNS. The shape and location of the PCTZ is variable in different types of nerve roots and in various species.6-10 For example, the peripheral myelin of the rat vagus nerve is found to extend centrally as isolated peripheral tissue islands.11 In other nerve roots such as lumbar ventral roots, cervical dorsal roots,12,13 and cranial nerves including oculomotor, trochlear, and abducent nerves,14,15 the PCTZ is usually dome shaped with the CNS compartment extending distally along the nerve root. Generally, the PCTZ is located within a few millimeters of the CNS surface in most nerve roots.

PCTZ interfaces usually consist of cell boundaries with different myelin components that contribute to transition zone formation with central and peripheral myelin, while the nerve fibers continue uninterrupted.16,17 Oligodendrocytes and Schwann cells, the myelinating glia of the CNS and PNS, respectively, form unique heminodes precisely at the PCTZ.18,19 Although both oligodendrocytes and Schwann cells are responsible for myelination of axons, they have different origins in the embryo: oligodendrocytes from neural tube and Schwann cells from neural crest. This leads to the distinct properties in their morphology and molecular components.20 For example, protein-zero (P-zero) is specifically expressed in Schwann cells while myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein (MOG) is detected in oligodendrocytes.17

The PCTZ of the cochlear nerve differs signiﬁcantly from other cranial nerves. Morphological studies using light microscopy suggest that the cochlear nerve presents an exceptionally long segment of CNS tissue extending into the PNS in a rat model. The PCTZ is located within the internal acoustic meatus during the first postnatal week in the rat model.21,22 However, it remains unclear whether the PCTZ of the mouse cochlear nerve forms at a pattern similar to the rat model. The knowledge of the mouse model is important because transgenic models are usually generated in the mouse, and these transgenic models may be utilized in the regenerative research in future. The objective of this study is to determine the formation of PCTZ along the cochlear nerve in the postnatal mouse.

sec.title: Animal and Groups
sec.p: All animal procedures were approved by local Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee. A total of 45 Swiss Webster mice were used in the following 9 groups (ages): postnatal day 0 (P0, the day of birth), 1, 3, 5, 7, 10, 14, 30, and 60 of either sex. The tissues from P0 mice were harvested at approximately 3 to 4 hours after birth. Each group comprised 5 replicates.

sec.title: Tissue Harvest and Sample Preparation
sec.p: A novel cochlea-cochlear nerve-brainstem model was used in this study. The animals at P0 to P14 were euthanized with decapitation and the animals at P30 and P60 were euthanized with an overdose of CO2. The inner ear, brainstem, and connecting cochlear nerve were dissected (Figure 1A), followed by ﬁxation in 4% paraformaldehyde (Sigma, St Louis, Missouri) overnight at 4°C. The specimens from P7 and beyond were decalciﬁed using 0.1M EDTA (Sigma, pH 7.4) for approximately 3 to 5 days. The samples were cryoprotected with 30% sucrose (Sigma) overnight at 4°C and cryosectioned on a cryostat (Leica, Wetzlar, Germany) at a thickness of 10 µm. The sectioning was started from the surface of the round window and was parallel to the modiolus. The sections containing the entire cochlea, the cochlear nerve, and the cochlear nucleus were collected for differential interference contrast (DIC) microscopy observation and the following immunofluorescence study.

caption.p: Determination of the peripheral and central nervous system transitional zone (PCTZ) of the cochlear nerve in a 2-month-old mouse. Scale: 50 µm.

sec.title: Immunoﬂuorescence Study
sec.p: Cryosections of mouse samples were incubated in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) containing 5% normal donkey serum (Jackson ImmunoResearch, West Grove, Pennsylvania) and 0.2% Triton X-100 (Sigma) for 30 minutes at room temperature, and then in the following primary antibodies overnight at 4°C: mouse monoclonal anti-MOG (1:100, Millipore, Billerica, Massachusetts) and chicken anti-P-zero (1:200, Millipore). DyLight conjugated secondary antibodies (Jackson ImmunoResearch, 2 hours incubation at room temperature) with appropriate filters were used to detect the expression of oligodendrocyte markers MOG and Schwann cell marker P-zero. The samples were observed using an epifluorescence microscopy or confocal microscopy (Leica), and the images were captured with a digital camera (Q-imaging, Surrey, British Columbia, Canada).

sec.title: Measurement of the Distance of CNS Tissue Projection and the Extension of PCTZ
sec.p: In this study, the extension of the CNS tissue was defined by the distance between the DIC-PCTZ (PCTZ observed using DIC microscopy) and the entry of cochlear nerve to the brainstem in the section closest to the middle of the modiolus (Figure 1A). For example, the PCTZ was observed in a P60 mouse using DIC microscopy (arrows in Figure 1A). The distance between the most distal point of PCTZ (point d) and the entry of cochlear nerve to the brainstem (points a and b) is determined as the distance between point c to point d, while c is the midpoint between points a and b. Quantitative studies were performed to determine the distance of the CNS tissue extension in P0 to P60 mice (n = 5).

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: The length of CNS extension in each group was analyzed using one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA). In this study, the statistical significance was defined as P value < .05.

sec.title: Determination of PCTZ in the Mouse Cochlear Nerve Using Immunofluorescence
sec.p: To determine whether CNS tissues are found centrally to the DIC-PCTZ and whether PNS tissues are located peripherally to the DIC-PCTZ, we used immunofluorescence to detect the expression of oligodendrocytes (CNS) and Schwann cells (PNS) along the mouse cochlear nerve. MOG is a mature oligodendrocyte marker that is specifically expressed on the outermost lamellae of the myelin sheath as well as the cell body and processes. In this study, we found that MOG was expressed centrally to the DIC-PCTZ while P-zero (indicating Schwann cells in the PNS) was exclusively observed distally to the DIC-PCTZ (Figures 1B-1C). In addition, we found that DIC-PCTZ overlapped with the PCTZ determined by the interface of the CNS (oligodendrocytes) and PNS (Schwann cells) using immunofluorescence (Figure 1D).

sec.title: Observation of the Location of PCTZ along the Mouse Cochlear Nerve
sec.p: To determine the location of PCTZ along the postnatal mouse cochlear nerve, DIC microscopy was used to observe PCTZ. Under DIC microscopy, it was found that DIC-PCTZ was located at the sub-arachnoid segment of the cochlear nerve at P0 (arrows in Figure 2A) and it gradually moved peripherally toward the basal cochlea, which was found within the internal auditory canal from P1 to P3 (arrows in Figure 2B). On P5, PCTZ was located within the modiolus at the base of the cochlea (arrows in Figure 2C). After P7, the PCTZ was found at the level of the spiral lamina of the basal cochlea and stayed at the similar position throughout adulthood (arrows in Figures 2D-2F, 1A).

caption.p: The peripheral and central nervous system transitional zone (PCTZ) of the postnatal mouse cochlear nerve was observed using the differential interference contrast (DIC) microscopy. Scale: 50 µm.

sec.title: Measurement of the Extension of the PCTZ along the Postnatal Mouse Cochlear Nerve
sec.p: The quantitative study shows that the distance of the CNS tissue extension along the cochlear nerve was 127 µm ± 28 µm, 315 µm ± 47 µm, 460 µm ± 65 µm, and 660 µm ± 66 µm on P0, 1, 3, and 5, respectively. The extension of CNS tissue was 830 µm ± 49 µm, 841 µm ± 50 µm, 822 µm ± 78 µm, 835 µm ± 26 µm, and 847 µm ± 72 µm for P7, 10, 14, 30, and 60, respectively (Table 1). Analyses using ANOVA showed the P value ≤ .01, indicating the statistically significant difference in the extension of CNS between groups P0, 1, 3, 5, 7, 10, 14, 30, and 60. However, the P value was ≥ .05 when the CNS extension was compared between groups P7, 10, 14, 30, and 60, suggesting no statistically significant difference in CNS extension between these groups. These results indicate that the PCTZ extended peripherally toward the cochlea during the first postnatal week and then progressed to approximately 800 µm in later postnatal days and stayed consistent throughout adulthood.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In this study, we utilize our newly developed cochlea-cochlear nerve-cochlear nucleus cryosection model to detail the formation of the PCTZ along the cochlear nerve in postnatal mice. We found that the PCTZ extended peripherally from the sub-arachnoid segment of cochlear nerve to the internal auditory meatus and then toward the basal cochlear turn during early postnatal stages.

Morphological studies of rat using light microscopy suggests that the cochlear nerve presents an exceptionally long segment of central nervous tissue extending into the PNS and the PCTZ is located within the internal acoustic meatus during the first postnatal week.21,22 In a rat model using antibodies specific to PNS myelin and CNS myelin, it is observed that the segment between the perikaryon of spiral ganglion neurons and the PCTZ expresses PNS myelin proteins along the cochlear nerve, while the myelin between the PCTZ and the brainstem is exclusively of the CNS type.22 In order to ascertain whether the DIC-PCTZ is the boundary of the CNS and PNS in the mouse cochlear nerve, we examined the expression of MOG (CNS) and P-zero (PNS) using immunofluorescence. We found that MOG was expressed centrally to the DIC-PCTZ and P-zero exclusively peripherally to the DIC-PCTZ. The distribution of the CNS and PNS tissue with relation to the PCTZ in the mouse model is consistent with previous studies using a rat model.

In this study, we found that the PCTZ extended peripherally along the cochlear nerve in early postnatal stage, reaches a mature pattern after P7 in a mouse model. However, the PCTZ formation pattern is different in the rat model. It was reported that the length of CNS projections in rat cochlear nerves continuously increases with time, from P0 to 1 year old.21 The daily rate of increase in length was rapid from P0 to P4, which was over 100 µm/day. It then slowed down from P4 to 1 year old and reached approximately 1.2 µm/day from P171 to P371. In the mouse model in this study, we found that the length of CNS projections of cochlear nerves increased rapidly from P0 to P7, which was over 50 µm/day. The CNS projections increased by approximately 200 µm during the first 24 hours after birth. Remarkably, the length of CNS tissue projections in the mouse cochlear nerve became stable after P7. The difference between the rat and the mouse in the pattern of CNS projection is unclear and additional experiments are required to address this question.

In summary, we found that the PCTZ extended peripherally toward the cochlea and reach a mature pattern along the mouse cochlear nerve during early postnatal stages. The knowledge of CNS tissue projection and PCTZ formation of the cochlear nerve will not only be critical to further research of myelination, but will also obtain clinical interest because of its relevance to nerve root disorders and regenerative medicine. Moreover, understanding the development of the PCTZ along the cochlear nerve is becoming increasingly important because of remarkable efforts in experimental stem cell transplantation into the spiral ganglion that aim at restoration of a functional auditory nerve after spiral ganglion neuron degeneration or rupture of the nerve.2,23,24
